title: Wildfires burn through over 7,500 acres in Virginia during bizarre weather week - Weather - News - Daily Express US
text: Wildfires burn through over 7,500 acres in Virginia during bizarre weather week At least five fires greater than 100 acres began to burn on Wednesday and continued on Thursday across Virginia in the Shenandoah Valley. Texas: Huge wildfire engulfs Walker County Dozens of [wildfires](/latest/wild-fires) have erupted along the Appalachian Mountains on Thursday as a cold front across the mid-Atlantic combines with humidity during a bizarre weather week. Wildfires have been reported from [Maryland](/latest/maryland) to [North Carolina](/latest/north-carolina), with the most amount of damage in [West Virginia](/latest/west-virginia) and [Virginia](/latest/virginia). At least five fires greater than 100 acres began to burn on Wednesday and continued on Thursday across Virginia in the Shenandoah Valley. State firefighters have responded to over 100 wildfires in the past two days, according to officials with the Virginia Department of Forestry. The fires have appeared to burn through more than 7,500 acres as evacuation orders are issued in specific counties. READ MORE: [Winter storm mapped as millions set to be pummeled on first weekend of Spring](/news/weather/131903/winter-storm-warning-northeast-forecast-flooding-rain-snow-spring) In Shenandoah County, a local state of emergency was issued and schools were closed. Multiple roads and highways in the county have also been temporarily shut down. The Virginia Department of Environmental Quality issued a health alert through Thursday night due to danger from heavy smoke. The department said: “Active children and adults should limit or reschedule strenuous outdoor activities until conditions improve. “People unusually sensitive to air pollution, especially those with heart or lung disease (including asthma), should avoid strenuous outdoor activities until conditions improve.” Orange-tinted skies were seen throughout Virginia on Thursday, and at least 10,000 electric outages were reported in the region due to wind gusts of more than 60mph. The National Weather Service office in Washington, DC, and Blacksburg, Virginia, said that the amount of fire activity is not unprecedented compared to wildfires over the past decades. On Friday night into Saturday, heavy rain is expected to soak the region, followed by another few dry days next week. author: AJ Vinayak
title: Experts foresee fundamental shift in tackling climate change - The Hindu BusinessLine
text:
Expressing concerns over increase in the recent monsoon patterns, increasing temperature and extreme weather events in the country, experts from different sectors stressed the need to explore strategies to mitigate the risks of climate change at the session on ‘Why the monsoon has been raining woes over the last few years’ at the businessline Agri and Commodity Summit 2025 titled ‘Shaping agriculture and agri-business in a changing climate’ in New Delhi on Friday.
Referring to 2024 being the warmest year, DS Pai, Scientist G, IMD, said no significant rainfall trend can be seen over the country in the last 125 years. Despite not showing any important trend, extreme rainfall events are increasing, particularly over the central part of India and along the West Coast and Northeast.
The North-East, which gets maximum rainfall, is showing a decreasing trend. Since the region is getting a lot of rain, this is not affecting. Interestingly, Northwest India, including Rajasthan, is witnessing increasing trend of rainfall.
Also read: From droughts to floods: How India is building climate-resilient agriculture Max and min temps up He said long time series of temperature from 1901-2024 shows that both maximum and minimum temperatures are showing significant trend. Now, both maximum as well as minimum temperature have seen a significant increase. Pai said all these aspects have got a significant impact on the agriculture.
Stating that there have been record levels of greenhouse gases just after Covid, he said development activities and a lot of deforestation are causing this. Deforestation is becoming a feedback kind of thing whereby there are more and more greenhouse gases.
Stating that climate change is real, Ajai Rana, Chairman, FSII and CEO, Savannah Seeds, said carbon dioxide concentration in atmosphere has gone up significantly over the years and so is methane emission. Apart from industries, agriculture is also responsible for this increase in green house gas emissions.
Giving the example of rice crop, he said the use of chemical fertilizers, especially urea, leads to release of nitrous oxide. They absorb more heat in the climate leading to increase in temperature. The oceans are becoming warmer and that is leading to the change in monsoon patterns.
On the impact of changes in rainfall patterns, he said the late rains at the time of flowering and seed setting lead to more diseases and insects and lead to drop in productivity.
Also read: Govt to revitalise cooperative sector to combat climate change Short-period rainfall Nabansu Chattopadhyay, Director, Agricultural Meteorology Division, WMO, said the district level data show Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand and eastern parts of UP witnessing lower rainfall over the years.
Stating that signal is clear, he said if we are not taking these as a benchmark now, then it will be not very supportive for the agriculture
Projections are also mentioning that there will be 4-16 per cent of increase in rainfall. The most important part is that this rainfall is very short period rainfall. This will impact agriculture production, Chattopadhyay said.
Speaking at the session, Neha Kumar, Head, South Asia Programme, Climate Bonds Initiative, said RBI had recently asked 15 banks to conduct an exercise on food risk to see how much of their assets are actually exposed to that. Agriculture lending forms part of priority sector lending and all banks have exposure to agriculture lending. Climate element of agriculture is still not factored into either the practices that need to be followed for farming or the lending or the investment practices.
Fundamental shift in tackling She emphasized the need for science, policy, economics and finance to come together for robust agricultural productivity of the country.
She said that more and more banks are hiring climate scientists. “There is going to be a fundamental shift in how you will tackle climate change, especially from the agri point of view,” she said.
Touching upon inflation, she said food inflation was in the region of 2.9 or something until 2020. After that it has doubled. The usual demand supply production consumption metrics to determine price are no longer following a predictable pattern, climate change has become an endemic source of disruption, and that is also causing sort of persistent food inflation, she said.
Subramani Ra Mancombu of businessline moderated the session.
The businessline Agri and Commodity Summit 2025 is presented by Nabard and co-powered by Federation of Seed Industry of India (FSSI) in association with Yara.
The Associate Partners are NCDEX, Indofil, Bayer, Hindustan Urvarak & Rasayan Ltd, Kribhco Agri, NSE, Aqua Group and Tamil Nadu Agricultural University. The Banking Partner is State Bank of India while the Broadcast Partner is NDTV Profit.

author: Editorial Board
title: Buffering...
text:
According to WISPAP nation’s internet speed has nosedived by a staggering 30-40 per cent By Editorial Board August 16, 2024
A representational image showing a person using a mobile phone. — AFP/File Welcome to Pakistan, where internet ‘speed’ has become the latest oxymoron. If you’re finding yourself stuck in an endless buffering loop, fret not; you’re not alone. According to the Wireless and Internet Service Providers Association of Pakistan (WISPAP), the nation’s internet speed has nosedived by a staggering 30-40 per cent. That’s not just a speed bump; it’s a full-on roadblock. If the internet were any slower, we’d be using carrier pigeons. The root of this digital debacle seems to be increased security and surveillance measures. Imagine a firewall so comprehensive it turns the internet into a digital sloth. WISPAP has linked the speed issues to increased security and surveillance whose aftermath might result in severe economic consequences as well. By many accounts, the government’s alleged ‘trial run’ of this firewall has morphed into a nightmare for e-commerce and online businesses whose very survival could be at stake. Meanwhile, the nation’s WhatsApp users are suffering from painfully slow uploads and downloads.
Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif-led coalition government and the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) have remained quiet as millions across the country continue to face trouble accessing internet services due to limited connectivity, particularly while using mobile data in some regions. Not only that, government ministers have not only acknowledged that a firewall trial is going on in the country but also defended it as a cyber security measure that every government in the world takes. This is a claim that has been debunked by digital rights experts in Pakistan who say that firewalls are essentially a form of pre-censorship that should have no place in any democracy.
In this day and age, it is amazing to see the government talking about web management systems and firewalls. When a government – a democratically elected one – starts to justify censorship, that should be a cause of concern for the country’s citizens because it essentially means the government does not believe in freedom of speech and expression. This is 2024 – the internet is not some novelty luxury but a fundamental need. It seems though that the state would rather have us sitting in caves around bonfires, what with a slow WhatsApp, a ban on X (formerly Twitter), and even blackouts at times. In a democracy, the internet is not disrupted. In a democracy, freedom of expression is guaranteed with limitations on incitement to violence and hate speech. However, while we do not take any action against hate speech or incitement to violence, we are quick to ban social media platforms and slow down the internet because the state does not have any counter-narrative to fake news or propaganda. So what exactly is the government’s big plan to save ‘Digital Pakistan’? A start could be to stop treating the internet like a nuisance and start seeing it as a vital economic artery. If Pakistan continues down this path of digital doom, it might find itself more isolated than a dial-up user in a fiber-optic world.

author: Claudia Espinoza
title: Lluvias apagan incendios forestales en Puebla, no reportan afectaciones | El Heraldo de México
text: Puebla. Debido a las lluvias de las últimas horas y trabajo de brigadistas, se extinguieron los últimos tres incendios forestales en el estado de Puebla, luego de una intensa ola de calor sufrida. Se logró el control de los últimos incendios en Huitzilan, Xochitlán y Tlahuapan, informó la Secretaría de Medio Ambiente del Estado de [Puebla](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/20/momento-exacto-en-que-conductor-atropella-cortejo-funebre-en-tepeaca-deja-personas-heridas-video-614203.html). El gobernador de Puebla, Sergio Salomón Céspedes Peregrina, en redes sociales externó su gratitud y felicitaciones a quienes trabajaron en las labores para apagarlos incendios forestales. Lluvias, fuertes vientos e incluso posible actividad eléctrica se espera en el estado de Puebla por el paso de la [depresión tropical Alberto.](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/20/estos-son-los-municipios-de-oaxaca-que-estan-en-riesgo-por-las-fuertes-lluvias-614182.html) Sigue leyendo: [Alberto: ¿Qué es una depresión tropical y cómo seguirá afectando hoy, 20 de junio?](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/20/alberto-que-es-una-depresion-tropical-como-seguira-afectando-hoy-20-de-junio-614174.html) Protección Civil del estado de Puebla apunta que las precipitaciones están pronosticadas hasta el próximo sábado 22 de junio, esto debido al desplazamiento hacia el oeste del fenómeno natural. Las regiones más afectadas serían las Sierras Norte, Nororiental y Negra, así como Valle Serdán, mientras que el resto del estado espera lluvias de 25 a 40 milímetros. ¿Qué hacer ante las intensas lluvias? La temporada de lluvias puede traer consigo una serie de desafíos para la población en general, sin embargo es posible minimizar sus efectos negativos. La prevención de afectaciones por lluvias comienza con la preparación del hogar, es fundamental revisar y mantener el techo en buen estado, asegurándose de que no haya tejas sueltas o dañadas que puedan permitir filtraciones. Además, es importante limpiar regularmente las canaletas y desagües para evitar obstrucciones que puedan causar inundaciones. Sellar grietas en paredes y ventanas es otra medida esencial para prevenir la entrada de agua. Considerar la instalación de protectores contra inundaciones, como barreras y sistemas de drenaje, en áreas propensas a inundarse puede hacer una gran diferencia. Asimismo, equiparse con suministros de emergencia es crucial, un botiquín de primeros auxilios, suficiente agua potable y alimentos no perecederos para al menos 72 horas, linternas con baterías de repuesto y un radio a pilas son elementos básicos que no deben faltar. Diseñar un plan de emergencia que incluya rutas de evacuación y puntos de reunión puede salvar vidas. Guardar documentos importantes en bolsas impermeables o en una caja fuerte a prueba de agua es otra medida preventiva clave. Además, revisar la póliza de seguro para asegurarse de que cubra daños por inundaciones es fundamental. Durante las lluvias, es crucial evitar zonas inundadas y no intentar cruzar calles anegadas, ya que pueden ser peligrosas. Desconectar aparatos eléctricos en caso de riesgo de inundación y seguir las recomendaciones de las autoridades son medidas adicionales que ayudan a proteger a la familia y el hogar. Con estas precauciones, es posible enfrentar la temporada de lluvias con mayor seguridad y tranquilidad. LA/TJM

author: L_104918
title: 打造文旅消费新引擎 2025年闽清县沉浸式剧本大赛举办
text:
2025年07月14日08:42 | 小字号
7月12日，“闽韵千年 清见未来”2025年闽清县沉浸式剧本大赛在位于福州市闽清县的宏琳厝举办。来自全国各地的参赛团队用精彩的剧本和别出心裁的演绎，为现场观众带来了一场沉浸式的文化盛宴。
作为闽清县推动文旅融合的重要举措，活动自6月10日启动以来，历经剧本征集、评选等阶段，吸引了全国各地的剧本创作者踊跃参与，共征集到原创剧本43个，涵盖行浸式剧本、剧本研学、剧本杀、实景剧本杀、剧本游等多种形式。活动通过沉浸式剧本载体实现“文化体验—消费转化”闭环，将文旅资源转化为游客可触摸、可共情的故事场景，深度激活闽清县的文化基因，让游客在沉浸式体验中感受闽清的独特魅力，打造闽清县文旅消费的新引擎，推动闽清县文旅经济高质量发展。
获奖剧本《厝里梅香》表演
经过由国内知名文旅专家组成的评审团严格评选，最终6部优秀作品脱颖而出。其中，剧本《宏琳千梦》获一等奖；《青橄榄的杀意》《梅溪暗涌》两部剧本获二等奖；《宏琳厝：家国回响》《清穿宏琳厝》《厝里梅香》三部剧本获三等奖。这些作品巧妙地将闽清的名山林海、碧水温泉、古厝民居等旅游资源与礼乐文化、状元文化、华侨文化等有机结合，展现了闽清深厚的文化底蕴和创新表达。
颁奖仪式在中国最大的单体古民居宏琳厝举行。活动主办方表示，这次活动是闽清文旅创新发展的重要尝试，通过沉浸式剧本这一年轻人喜闻乐见的形式，让传统文化焕发新活力。中国文化产业协会沉浸式文旅产业专业委员会常务副秘书长徐宁对获奖剧本给予了高度评价，认为这些剧本“既有文化深度，又具市场潜力”。
游客参与获奖剧本沉浸式体验
活动现场，200余名游客分成多个体验小组，在专业演员的引导下，亲身参与获奖剧本的沉浸式体验。参与者穿梭于宏琳厝的厅堂院落，通过角色扮演、线索解谜等方式，深度感受闽清文化的独特魅力。来自福州的游客王女士兴奋地表示：“这种旅游体验太新颖了，既能游玩又能学习历史文化，孩子们也玩得很开心。”
当天举办的“桃醉闽清”农文旅集市同样人气满满。集市展位集中展示了下祝水蜜桃等闽清特色农产品，以及闽清非遗技艺——闽清窑、福文化文创产品。集市特别设置了与剧本内容联动的互动游戏，游客完成挑战即可获得限定礼品，进一步增强了活动的趣味性和参与感。
“桃醉闽清”农文旅集市
据悉，获奖剧本经过专业团队优化后，将作为常态化文旅项目在宏琳厝落地实施，成为福建省古厝活化利用的又一成功案例。闽清县文化旅游投资有限公司董事长刘思炜表示：“我们通过‘文化+旅游+剧本’的创新模式，让这座百年古厝焕发新生。计划定期推出不同主题的剧本体验活动，并开发配套文创产品，打造完整的文旅产业链。”这一创新举措不仅为宏琳厝创建国家4A级旅游景区提供有力支撑，更探索出一条通过沉浸式体验活化古厝、传承文化的新路径，打造了文旅融合发展的新样板，为县域文旅产业转型升级提供了有益借鉴。
本次活动由闽清县文化体育和旅游局、闽清县文化旅游投资有限公司主办，中国文化产业协会沉浸式文旅产业专业委员会、福建未来文旅研究院、福州市旅游协会、闽清县坂东镇人民政府、闽清县下祝乡人民政府协办，闽清福旅旅游文化有限公司执行，旨在充分挖掘闽清县丰富的文旅资源，打造一批具有闽清特色的沉浸式文旅体验项目，丰富闽清文旅消费场景，提升闽清县文旅品牌竞争力。（文/图 福州市旅游协会）

title: Analysts foresee better crude palm oil prices in 2024 | Hellenic Shipping News Worldwide
text:
Analysts have foreseen better crude palm oil (CPO) prices in 2024, as El Nino weather is expected to affect palm oil supply.
RHB Investment Bank, the largest investment bank by asset size in Malaysia, said in its recent report that it expects CPO prices to trade higher – crossing the 4,000 ringgit (872 U.S. dollars) per ton mark – as supply should be somewhat affected by El Nino as well as the impact of lower fertilization activities in 2021 to 2022.
UOBKayHian, one of Asia’s largest brokerage firms headquartered in Singapore, also expects CPO prices to trade higher in 2024 with an average price of 4,200 ringgit per ton, following the average of 3,850 ringgit per ton recorded year to date in 2023.
The higher price expectation is also underpinned by potentially lower palm oil production, a challenging outlook for global vegetable oil supply and higher palm oil demand.
Affin Hwang Investment Bank, one of Malaysia’s leading bank-backed investment banking groups, also expects CPO prices to trend higher in 2024, attributable to the El Nino phenomenon that is expected to have an impact on the global supply of edible oils and their prices.
The research house’s CPO price assumption for 2024 is 4,200 ringgit to 4,400 ringgit per ton.
Affin Hwang also expects Malaysia’s plantation sector earnings to jump 24 percent year-on-year in 2024 from a low base in 2023 due mainly to higher CPO price expectations while Malaysia production could be flattish year-on-year. (1 ringgit equals 0.22 U.S. dollar)
Source: Xinhua
